moves.1. d4 d5 2. c4 c6 3. Nf3 Bg4: Not the best of moves, but I'll give my opponent credit.
moves.4. Ne5 Bf5 5. Nc3 f6: Opening up a weakness in Black's king side and hindering the development of the g8 knight.
moves.6. Nf3 Bg4: Looks like he really wants that pin to happen.
moves.7. e3 Nh6 8. Be2 Bxf3: Why Black decided to take now I'll never know.
moves.9. Bxf3 e6 10. Qb3: I prepare an attack on b7 whilst giving my c4 pawn some support.
moves.10... Qd7 11. e4: I challenge the d5 pawn further.
moves.11... e5: Threatening my unprotected d4 pawn. I must take with it to protect from my opponent getting a passed pawn after exd4.
moves.12. dxe5 dxc4 13. Qxc4 fxe5: Now, after the exchanges take place, the d file is open and the f file semi open. Black has an isolated pawn on e5 while my pawn on e4 is only temporarily isolated (if you would even call it so).
moves.14. O-O b5 15. Qb3: I want to maintain control of the a2-g8 diagonal to further my plans.
moves.16. a4: It was either this move or 16. a3, which would give my queen a safe haven on a2 after 16...a4. I wanted to be agressive and maybe mess up Black's pawn structure, or open up the position a bit more.
moves.18. Bxh6 gxh6 19. Bh5+: With no enemy pawn on the g file and my bishop and queen converging on f7, my attack will become deadly.
moves.19... Ke7: If 19...Kd8 then I'll put one of my rooks on d1 (but then again I didn't even consider 20...Bd6).
moves.20. Qf7+ Kd8 21. Rad1 Bd6: This move would have worked better for my opponent after he had immediately put his king on d8 after 19.Bh5+
moves.22... Kc7 23. Qxh8 Qxa4 24. Bg4: I planned on putting my queen on c8 after my opponent took the pawn (and kindof wasted a move).
moves.24... Qc6 25. Qc8+ Kb6 26. Qxc6+: Seeing that I could attack no further with the queen immediately, I exchange queens.
moves.26... Kxc6 27. f4 b3: It probably would have been easier for Black to take on f4, but then I get a passed pawn on e4.
moves.28. f5 Na6 29. f6 Nb4: My opponent completely ignores the passed pawn for the time being
moves.31... Kb5: Instead of protecting the bishop with Rd8 ( if 32. f8=Q, then 32...Rxf8 33. Rdxd6+, Kc7), my opponent retreats his king.
moves.32. Rdxd6 a4 33. Nc3+: I now have Black in a forced mate, but at the time I did not think twice to find the quickest way to achieve mate (movewise); I wanted to end the game in less time (especially since this board was the last one playing).
moves.33... Kc4 34. Be6+: Yes, I know, Be2 would have been better.
And that's the way the cookie crumbles. Commenting and rating are appreciated.
